moves.1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bc4: White chooses to follow development, along the lines of the italian party...
moves.3... h6: theory usually follows with Bc5, c3, Nf6, d4: not only is the text move weakening Blacks' K-side, it is also loss of tempo; Black usually plays this, to counter Ng5 after Nf6: a bad idea...
moves.4. O-O Nf6 5. Re1 Bc5 6. c3: back to theory, but there is an important difference; White has already castled, and is ready to break up the center...
moves.6... O-O 7. d4 exd4 8. cxd4 Bb4 9. Bd2 R: not good: Black already needs to simplify, before White gains even more advantages; better Bxd2, Nbxd2...
moves.10. e5 Bxd2: not yet forced now, Black trades with the wrong intentions: rerouting the Knight to g5 to protect f7; better Nh7, followed by Qe7...
moves.11. Nbxd2 Nh7 12. Qb3 Qe7: the only way, to shield f7...
moves.13. d5: relentless: White has conquered the center...
moves.15... Ng5 16. d6: forcing matters: no option is Qe6...
moves.16... Nxf3+ 17. Qxf3 cxd6 18. Nxd6: with Nf3 still in place, exd6 would be winning: but this will work too...
moves.18... Rf8 19. Nxc8 Raxc8 20. Qxb7 Rcb8 2: securing enough advantages for an upcoming endgame...
moves.24... Rc8: not sure, what is best for Black here: White is ready for preparing mate...
moves.25... Rxf2: a desperate attempt: now, after Rxg2+, Qxg2, Qxg2+, Kxg2, Black still reaches nothing...
moves.26. Red1: finishing off the mating net: after Rd8+, all is over...
moves.26... Qe2: a losing and irrelevant move: tougher was Rf8...
moves.27. Rd7d8+: after Rxd8, Rxd8+, it is mate: so Black resigned...
